timeline.body: `org.eclipse.xtext.ui.editor.copyqualifiedname.DefaultCopyQualifiedNameService` is deprecated. We'll have to revisit this code and replace the deprecated API with the correct one. Corresponding change needs to be made in the `XbaseUiModule#bindCopyQualifiedNameService()` method.

replies.bodyText:
Please take a look at the conversion that was applied to the org.eclipse.xtext.naming.DefaultCopyQualifiedNameService - there we use a PolymorphicDispatcher.
I'm afraid we have to do the same here in order to remain backwards compatible.
replies.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText: I'll file a separate jira for this.

replies.bodyText: Does this work if declaredConstructors is null?
replies.author: tivervac

replies.bodyText:
declaredConstructors can be empty, but not null. PS - https://bit.ly/3dIG53z
Generally speaking, FluentIterable.from will throw a NPE if the passed param. is null.
replies.author: nbhusare

replies.bodyText:
declaredConstructors will still be null if resolvedFeatures is null.
These null checks look a little too xtendy to me. Many of the intermediate local vars will never be null if the actual receiver was present.
Please reverse the logic and exit early but otherwise keep a normal flow.
replies.author: szarnekow
szarnekow

replies.bodyText: It is going to be null if resolvedFeatures is null
replies.author: tivervac

replies.bodyText: You are right, I missed that.
replies.author: nbhusare

timeline.body: Populating a list to loop over the list on step later appears to be unnecessary. Maybe extract a few smaller methods to improve the readability and avoid the intermediate list here?
timeline.bodyText: Populating a list to loop over the list on step later appears to be unnecessary. Maybe extract a few smaller methods to improve the readability and avoid the intermediate list here?
timeline.bodyHTML: Populating a list to loop over the list on step later appears to be unnecessary. Maybe extract a few smaller methods to improve the readability and avoid the intermediate list here?
timeline.author: szarnekow

timeline.body: Same comment here as a few lines below: We create unnecessary lists and end up with a very long method. Maybe it's better to refactor this by extracting a few smaller methods.
timeline.bodyText: Same comment here as a few lines below: We create unnecessary lists and end up with a very long method. Maybe it's better to refactor this by extracting a few smaller methods.
timeline.bodyHTML: Same comment here as a few lines below: We create unnecessary lists and end up with a very long method. Maybe it's better to refactor this by extracting a few smaller methods.
timeline.author: szarnekow

timeline.bodyHTML:
I'd prefer a more straight forward

for(PlatformResource candidate: trace.getAllAssociatedLocations()) {
  if (languageInfo.equals(candidate.getLanguage()) {
    IStorage storage = candidate.getPlatformResource();
    if (storage != null) {
      return ..
    }
  }
}
return input;
timeline.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText:
The above code goes through all-the-candidates until it finds one for which storage != null. If you look at the original code (https://bit.ly/2wXAeXN), it gets the first candidate that matches the condition languageInfo.equals(candidate.getLanguage()), and uses it for further processing.
@szarnekow Is it possible for more than one candidate for which the condition languageInfo.equals(candidate.getLanguage()) is true?
replies.author: nbhusare

timeline.body: Not sure how often we do similar things in the code base, but I can imagine this logic to be moved to `ResolvedFeatures`, e.g. `findResolvedOperation(JvmOperation declaration)`
timeline.bodyText: Not sure how often we do similar things in the code base, but I can imagine this logic to be moved to ResolvedFeatures, e.g. findResolvedOperation(JvmOperation declaration)
timeline.bodyHTML: Not sure how often we do similar things in the code base, but I can imagine this logic to be moved to ResolvedFeatures, e.g. findResolvedOperation(JvmOperation declaration)
timeline.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText: The methods ResolvedFeatures#getAllOperations() and ResolvedFeatures#getDeclaredConstructors() are used in very few places, not for the same purpose as we have here. Nevertheless, I like your idea of adding methods #findResolvedOperation(JvmOperation declaration) (and  #findDeclaredConstructor(JvmConstructor constructor)) to the ResolvedFeatures class.
replies.author: nbhusare

commits_in_main.message: [eclipse/xtext#1679] removed last xtend bits from xbase.ui

timeline.body: Not a big fan of these usages of optionals. Checking for `isPresent` is usually not good style. You probably want to do something like `Iterables.tryFind(..).transform(node->getOffset() + 1).or(compositeNode::getEndOffset)`
timeline.bodyText: Not a big fan of these usages of optionals. Checking for isPresent is usually not good style. You probably want to do something like Iterables.tryFind(..).transform(node->getOffset() + 1).or(compositeNode::getEndOffset)
timeline.bodyHTML: Not a big fan of these usages of optionals. Checking for isPresent is usually not good style. You probably want to do something like Iterables.tryFind(..).transform(node->getOffset() + 1).or(compositeNode::getEndOffset)
timeline.author: szarnekow

replies.bodyText: Or preferably a plain for loop.
replies.author: szarnekow

timeline.body: The semantics of getAncestor do already imply the check of the element itself. Can be implemented as `return (IPackageFragmentRoot) element.getAncestor()`
